text: What does it mean that one solution of a linear system with $n$ variables is the trivial solution?
answerOptions: One of the linear objects that are represented by the system of equations lies on the coordinate axis.
The solution set of each equation contains the origin of $\mathbb{R}^n$.
The linear objects that are represented by the system of equations intersect in the the origin of $\mathbb{R}^n$.
correctAnswer: The solution set contains the origin of $\mathbb{R}^n$
The linear objects that are represented by the system of equations intersect in the the origin of $\mathbb{R}^n$
solution: Homogeneous linear systems always have a trivial solution in their solution set and a solution tuple $(x, y, ...) = (0, 0, ...)$ means that the linear systems intersect in the origin of $\mathbb{R}^n$ and finally, as the solution of the system of linear equations is an intersection of the solution sets of each equation, this means that if a system has a trivial solution, then each of the equations in that system also have a trivial solution.

text: Is $(x, y) = (3, 0)$ a solution of this system? $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 6 \\ 4x - y = 1 \end{cases}$
solution: $(x, y) = (3, 0)$ is not a solution of the second equation

text: Consider the equation $x + y + 1 = 0$ in the real variables $x,y,z$.
solution: It is linear because a sum of multiples of the variables plus a constant term should be zero. It is consistent (and hence not inconsistent) because $(x,y,z)=(-1,0,0)$ is a solution. It is not homogeneous because there is a non-zero constant term.

text: The following linear system is $\begin{cases} 3x + y = 0 \\ 2x + 1 - 3y = 1 \end{cases}$
solution: The system is consistent because there is a solution $(x, y) = (0, 0)$. It is also homogeneous as $2x + 1 - 3y = 1 \leftrightarrow 2x - 3y = 0$.

text: The following linear system is $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 5 \\ 4x - y = 1 \end{cases}$
solution: The system is consistent because there is the solution $(x, y) = (\frac{4}{7}, \frac{9}{7})$. It is not homogeneous because $(x,y)=(0,0)$ is not a solution.

text: An equation in a linear system corresponds to a ...
solution: This is by definition of the augmented matrix.

text: Each column of the augmented matrix corresponds to a variable of the linear system
solution: A column of the augmented matrix corresponds to a variable.

text: What is the solution set of the linear system $\begin{cases} x-2y=1 \\ z=5 \end{cases}$ in the variables $x,y,z$, knowing that there is precisely one free variable?
solution: All given sets have the correct structure. The first set is not the solution set because setting $t=0$ does not give a solution. The third set is not correct because $(1,2,0)$ (corresponding to the coefficients of $t$) is not a solution to the associated homogeneous linear system. The empty set is not the solution set because there is the solution $(2,1,5)$. The second set is the solution set. Indeed, setting $t=0$ gives a solution and $(2,1,0)$ (corresponding to the coefficients of $t$) is a non-trivial solution to the associated homogeneous linear system. Finally, there cannot be more solutions as we know that there is only one free variable.

text: What is the solution set of the linear system $\begin{cases} 2x + y = a \\ 2x + y = b \end{cases}$, where $a$ and $b$ are distinct real numbers?
solution: The equations are identical in everything but constant term, so by subtracting one equation from another we get $0 = a - b$, where $a \neq b$, so $a - b \neq 0$ and therefore the system is not consistent

text: Select correct matrix, representing the linear system $\begin{cases} 2y+z-1 = -x \\ 2z = 3-5z \\ 3x+z = 0 \end{cases}$
solution: The constant terms in the augmented matrix must have the signs as they are on the right side of the equations.

text: Select correct statement(s):
answerOptions: In the solution set we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables
In the solution set we express the free variables in terms of the leading variables
correctAnswer: In the solution set we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables
solution: In the solution set, we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables. This is because the free variables can take any value, and the leading variables are dependent on these values.

text: Select correct statement(s):
answerOptions: A parameter is assigned to all of the free variables
A parameter is assigned to all of the leading variables
correctAnswer: A parameter is assigned to all of the free variables
solution: In the solution set, we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables. This is because the free variables can take any value, and the leading variables are dependent on these values.

text: Consider a linear system (over $\mathbb{R}$). Mark the properties that are equivalent to the system being homogeneous.
answerOptions: It has the same number of equations and variables
The system has at least one solution
The number $0$ is a solution to the system
The number $0$ is a solution to at least one equation
The right hand side of each equation is zero
The constant term of each equation is zero
Each equation of the system is homogeneous
correctAnswer: The constant term of each equation is zero
The number $0$ is a solution to the system
solution: Conditions that are not equivalent to being homogeneous: it has the same number of equations and variables; the system has at least one solution ($3x=5$ is not homogeneous); the number $0$ is a solution to at least one equation ($2x=0$, $3x=5$ is not homogeneous); the constant term in each equation is zero ($3x-5=0$ is not homogeneous).
subTopic: Homogeneity, cardinality of the solution set

text: Which of the following linear systems (over $\mathbb{R}$) have at least one solution?
answerOptions: All linear systems with the same number of equations and variables
All linear systems such that each equation has a solution
solution: All consistent linear systems have a solution (definition), all homogeneous linear systems have a trivial solution.
subTopic: Homogeneity, cardinality of the solution set

text: Which of the following linear systems (over $\mathbb{R}$) have infinitely many solutions?
answerOptions: All consistent not homogeneous linear systems
All linear systems having at least two distinct solutions
All linear systems such that each equation has infinitely many solutions
correctAnswer: All linear systems having at least two distinct solutions
solution: If a system has at least two distinct solutions, it means that there are infinitely many.
subTopic: Homogeneity, cardinality of the solution set

text: How many distinct solutions can a linear system (over $\mathbb{R}$) have?
answerOptions: Not more than the number of equations in the system
solution: Two lines/planes can only: not intersect at all if they are parallel, intersect at every point if they lie one on another or intersect at a single point/line.
subTopic: Homogeneity, cardinality of the solution set

text: Which of the following operations can be performed to the augmented matrix of a linear system while solving the system?
answerOptions: Multiplying a row by any scalar
Multiplying a row by a non-zero scalar
Add a row to a different row
Add to a row a multiple of a different row
Add to a row a multiple of itself
correctAnswer: Multiplying a row by a non-zero scalar
Add a row to a different row
Add to a row a multiple of a different row
solution: All the options are correct apart from the first and sixth as we can not multiply a row by 0 and we can not (in general case) add to a row a multiple of itself, as it might nullify the row.

text: The order of the elementary row operations matters.
solution: Elementary row operations can be performed in any order.

text: Performing elementary row operations changes the equations but not the common solutions.
solution: Performing elementary row operations do not change the common solutions, that is why we can use them to solve the linear systems.

text: Removing a zero row or column affects the solution set.
solution: Zero columns indicate that the certain variable is not affecting the system. Zero rows, on the other hand, indicate that certain equation.

text: The linear system $\begin{cases} x - y = 3 \\ 2x - 2y = k \end{cases}$ cannot have a unique solution, regardless of the value of $k \in \mathbb{R}$.
solution: By multiplying the first equation by 2, we get a system $\begin{cases} 2x - 2y = 6 \\ 2x - 2y = k \end{cases}$. Now subtracting the first system from the second we obtain a system $\begin{cases} 2x - 2y = 6 \\ 0 = k - 6 \end{cases}$. The second equation has infinitely many solutions if $k = 6$. In this case there are infinitely many solutions as the solution of $2x - 2y = 6$ will inevitably have a free variable. On the other hand, if $k \neq 6$, then the second equation will have no solutions, so the whole system will be inconsistent.

text: Are these two augmented matrices row equivalent? $\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 7 & 2 &\bigm| & 1 \\ 8 & 1 & 2 &\bigm| & 3 \\ 3 & 3 & 6 &\bigm| & 0 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 4 & -4 &\bigm| & 1 \\ 9 & 5 & -2 &\bigm| & 4 \\ 3 & 3 & 6 &\bigm| & 0 \end{pmatrix}$
solution: $Row_1 = Row_1 - Row_3, \ Row_2 = Row_2 + Row_1$

text: The linear system with corresponding augmented matrix is consistent $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 &\bigm| 4 \\ 0 & 0 &\bigm| -1 \end{pmatrix}$
solution: Row $(0 \ 0 \ | \ -1)$ represents an equation $0 = -1$, which is inconsistent.

text: If each equation in a consistent linear system is multiplied through by a nonzero constant, then all solutions to the new system can be obtained by multiplying solutions from the original system by the same constant.
solution: Multiplication by a nonzero constant is an elementary row operation and elementary row operations do not change the solution set.

text: Can we perform elementary column operations to the augmented matrix of a linear system while solving the system in the canonical way?
solution: The columns are assigned to variables and hence, for example, we are not allowed to permute them. Note: technically we can permute the columns, but beware that it would change the order of variables, leading to another answer tuple, so it is HIGHLY discouraged (i.e, not allowed).

text: In row echelon form, the first entry in each non-zero row is always 1.
solution: The first entry in each non-zero row is called the leading entry, and it is not necessarily 1.

text: If the row echelon form has a leading 1 in the last column, the system is not solvable.
solution: If a matrix in row echelon form has a leading 1 in the last column, it means that this row would look like this: $(0 \ 0 \ 0 \ ... \ 0 \ | \ 1)$, resulting in an equation $0 = 1$, which does not have a solution, so the whole system is unsolvable.

text: Which of the following statements is true about the row echelon form of a matrix?
answerOptions: The leading entry of each non-zero row is 1
The leading entry of each non-zero row is to the right of the leading entry of the previous row
All entries below a leading entry are zero
correctAnswer: The leading entry of each non-zero row is to the right of the leading entry of the previous row
All entries below a leading entry are zero
solution: The leading entry is not mandatory a 1, so the first and second statements are incorrect. However, the third and fourth statements are correct, as the leading entries follow a 'ladder' pattern in the row echelon form.

text: In row echelon form, the number of non-zero rows is equal to the number of leading variables.
solution: In row echelon form, each leading variable corresponds to a pivot position in the matrix. A pivot position is the first non-zero entry in each row. Therefore, the number of non-zero rows in the matrix is equal to the number of pivot positions, which is also the number of leading variables.

text: In row echelon form, the leading entry of each non-zero row is to the ... of the leading entry of the previous row.
solution: The leading ones should follow a 'ladder' pattern in the row echelon form, so each nonzero entry in the line below should be in the more right column.

text: Row echelon form and reduced row echelon form are...
answerOptions: Only reduced row echelon form is unique
Only row echelon form is unique
correctAnswer: Only reduced row echelon form is unique
solution: There are infinitely many row echelon forms as we can create a new row echelon form by simply multiplying one of the rows by a non-zero scalar. In the case of the reduced row echelon form, each leading entry must be a 1 and be the only non-zero entry in each row, so we cannot multiply rows by a scalar or add them up, making the reduced row echelon form unique for every matrix.

text: The number of leading variables is equal to the number of non-zero rows in the row echelon form.
solution: In row echelon form, each non-zero row corresponds to a leading variable. Therefore, the number of leading variables is equal to the number of non-zero rows.

text: If all variables are leading, the system has a unique solution.
solution: If every variable is a leading variable, there are no free variables. This means each variable can be solved uniquely, leading to a unique solution.

text: We express the leading variables as a sum of multiples of the free variables and possibly a constant term.
solution: In a system of linear equations, leading variables are expressed in terms of free variables and constants.

text: How many linear equations are required to define a line in $\mathbb{R}^3$?
solution: In $\mathbb{R}^3$, a line is defined by the intersection of two planes, each represented by a linear equation. Therefore, two linear equations are required.

text: In $\mathbb{R}^2$, the equation $0x + 0y = 0$ represents a line.
solution: This equation represents the entire $\mathbb{R}^2$, as it is always true.

text: In $\mathbb{R}^2$, the solution set to a linear equation can be:
solution: Only a linear object can be a solution of a linear system.

text: The lines represented by the following linear system are: $\begin{cases} -4x + y = 3 \\ \frac{1}{2}x + 2y = -2 \end{cases}$
solution: Recall from high-school algebra that lines in $\mathbb{R}^2$ are perpendicular if the coefficients at $y$ are the same and the product of coefficients at $x$ equals $-1$.

text: Summing two solutions of an inhomogeneous linear system gives a solution of the inhomogeneous linear system.
solution: The sum of two solutions of an inhomogeneous system is generally not a solution of the same system because the inhomogeneous part (constant term) does not cancel out.

text: Summing two solutions of a homogeneous linear system gives a solution of the homogeneous linear system.
solution: The set of solutions to a homogeneous linear system forms a vector space. Therefore, the sum of any two solutions is also a solution.

text: Summing a solution of an inhomogeneous linear system and a solution of the corresponding homogeneous linear system gives a solution of the:
solution: The set of solutions to a homogeneous linear system forms a vector space. Therefore, the sum of any two solutions is also a solution.

text: Is there a bound on the number of elementary row operations needed to transform a matrix to row echelon form?
solution: The number of elementary row operations required is bounded by a function of the number of rows and columns of the matrix.

text: Does the order of elementary row operations matter when performing Gaussian elimination?
solution: The final row echelon form will be the same regardless of the order of the row operations, although the intermediate steps may differ.

text: Is it necessary to perform elementary row operations in the same order?
solution: Different orders of row operations can still lead to the same row echelon form, so the specific order is not necessary.

text: The associated homogeneous linear system is the parallel object (line, plane, etc) through the origin.
solution: The solution set of a homogeneous system always includes the origin, making it a subspace (line, plane, etc.) through the origin.

text: If the reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix for a linear system has a row of zeros, then the system must have infinitely many solutions.
solution: If the system has more equations than the number of variables and one of the equations is repeating, then it is possible that the augmented matrix would have a zero row but the system will still have a single solution.

text: The number of free variables is the number of variables minus the number of leading variables.
solution: Free variables are those that are not leading variables, so their number is the total number of variables minus the number of leading variables.

text: The number of leading variables is the number of non-zero rows in the row echelon form.
solution: Free variables are those that are not leading variables, so their number is the total number of variables minus the number of leading variables.

text: If a matrix is in reduced row echelon form, then it is also in row echelon form.
solution: The reduced row echelon form does not contradict the simple row echelon form, as there are still no nonzero entries below the leading ones.

text: If an elementary row operation is applied to a matrix that is in row echelon form, the resulting matrix will still be in row echelon form.
solution: If an elementary row operation is applied to a matrix that is in row echelon form this can disrupt the row echelon form. For example, adding two rows might introduce a non-zero entry below a leading entry, violating the row echelon form’s requirements.

text: If there are more unknowns than equations, there must be free variables.
solution: With more unknowns than equations, not all variables can be leading, so there must be free variables.

text: If there are more equations than variables, the system is unsolvable.
solution: Nothing can be said about the system.

text: The order of equations in a system is important.
solution: The order of equations in a system of linear equations does not affect the solution set. The system can be solved regardless of the order in which the equations are written.

text: The solution set of a system of linear equations is the intersection of the solution sets of the individual equations.
solution: The solution to a system of linear equations is the set of points that satisfy all the equations simultaneously.

text: If two equations in a system are the same, one of them can be deleted.
solution: We can get rid of one of them as the difference between those equations is a zero row.

text: Consider the system: $\begin{cases} 7x + y = 1 \\ x - 2y = 0 \end{cases}$ Select the correct assertion:
solution: In any linear system the number of variables is actually infinite, however, in this case only 2 variables have nonzero coefficients.

text: The number of leading variables is at most the number of variables that appear in the equation.
solution: In case of existence of a unique solution of the system, each variable is the leading variable.

text: The number of free variables is at most the number of leading variables.
solution: The number of free variables is determined by the total number of variables minus the number of leading variables. Therefore, the number of free variables can be less than or equal to the total number of variables but not necessarily less than or equal to the number of leading variables.
